properties.site_description: Longview Park is on the grounds of the Marist College Campus.  This stretch of riverfront was the center of collegiate rowing in the late 1800s, with national and world championships happening here, along with tens of thousands of spectators  even some that would ride rail cars being propelled down the tracks at the same speed as the rowers!  Featured in this beautiful riverfront park is the historic Cornell Boathouse, the Marist College Boathouse, a fishing pier, and a gazebo with scenic views of the Hudson River and the Walkway Over the Hudson. The Cornell Boathouse, once used by Cornells crew team during their training and racing, was acquired in 1977 by Marist College and went through a 5 year remodeling in 2004.  Trails on the property are part of the Hudson River Greenway Trail System, and will eventually connect to trails at Waryas Park to the south, and Quiet Cove Park to the north.  Marist College controls access to the Park, with normal hours from dawn to dusk.  Contact the College for more information.

properties.site_description: Quiet Cove Riverfront Park was originally part of the estate of John Aspinwall Roosevelt (President Franklin Roosevelts Uncle), and later part of the Hudson River Psychiatric Center. Just upriver from Marist College, it was part of intercollegiate rowing scene in the early 1900s, and is home to the historic (and now restored) Navy Boathouse, air-conditioned and available to rent for private and public events. Quiet Cove offers something for everyone! A new Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) compliant kayak and canoe launch has just been installed.  Enjoy stunning vistas of the Hudson River while relaxing on our front porch. Spacious picnic areas offer enough space to accommodate your next gathering. Then, top the day off with accessible and tranquil pathways leading to two observation decks on the river for fishing or the perfect photograph!

properties.address: Vernon Blvd.  bet.  33rd Rd. and 34th Ave

properties.address: 201 John T O'Leary Blvd,  South Amboy
RT-9W,  RT-308 West, 2.2mi to Rhinecliff RR,  Right Hutton St
properties.site_description: The Rhinecliff Landing Park has a history as deep as the Hudson River that it provides access to.  It has been a landing since the first Europeans that sailed up the Hudson, gaining prominence as the river access for Rhinebeck.  Once the Hudson River Railroad (later the New York Central) was completed in 1851, the Rhinecliff dock became the transfer point for all the sloops and steamboats waiting to transfer goods to the railroad.  It was also the western terminus of the Rhinebeck and Connecticut Railroad, which carried milk and produce from as far away as Sharon, Connecticut. With the decline of the railroads in the 1950s the freight buildings on the Landing site were demolished to make way for new bulkheads and the town park that now exists. With picnic tables, grills, pavilions, and benches, it is the perfect place to see a gorgeous sunset, or to launch your power boat or kayak from the public dock.

properties.url_public: The Yonkers Yacht Club  We make boating on the Hudson River fun and easy

properties.site_description: Bowdoin Park is a picturesque 301-acre park located on the banks of the Hudson River, on Sheafe Road in the town of Poughkeepsie, NY. Scenic views of the Hudson River, open areas for picnicking, a playground area and a water spray park are just the beginning of what Bowdoin Park has to offer. Into sports? We offer facilities to play soccer and two softball fields as well as a nationally recognized cross-country race course. Or stroll along more than four miles of well-maintained trails. View the wetland areas from our boardwalks, observe the wildlife, or sit on a bench and enjoy the beauty of the park. Having an event? Bowdoin Park now offers five pavilions, a community room, two softball fields, two soccer fields, a sand volleyball court, gaga ball pit and half-court basketball court, and dont forget the historic Ellessdie Chapel or the Maple Knoll Lodge, which are perfect for weddings, receptions and holiday parties.

Carnwath Farms Historic Site & Park is located in the Wheeler Hill Historic District. The grounds are open to the public for hiking and recreational activities. Come check out Frances Reese Cultural Center, home to the Sports Museum of Dutchess County and take a hike along the Wappinger Greenway Trail.

A beautiful view of the Hudson River can be enjoyed from the pavilion at Castle Point Park. The park contains two baseball fields as well as a playground area for the children. This park is home to the Kenneth A. Browne Memorial that honors a Town of Wappinger Resident who was killed in action during the Korean War.

Dominican Camp Overlook used to be a summer camp and in 2007 became a Scenic Hudson Property protecting 72 acres with 60 of it being federally designated wetlands. This is an important addition to the other parks and historic sites along the Hudson River corridor and has become a linking part of the 8-mile waterfront trail that connects them. The trail is 1.85 miles long and meanders through forests, wetlands and streams and past a scenic outlook that has benches and views of the Hudson River. Dogs are allowed on a leash.
Fishermans Park is focused on fishing!  With access to Wappinger Lake, there is ample parking from which a short walk will bring you to the lake shore.

Fran Reese Audubon Sanctuary is named after Frances (Franny) Reese (1917 to 2003) who was an environmentalist and founder of Scenic Hudson.  She worked to conserve land in the Hudson River region for 40 years. On this ridgeline are almost three miles of trails along historic carriage roads, offering amazing views of Wappingers Lake, the Hudson River, and mountains beyond.  These trails are part of the Wappingers Creek Greenway Trail, a loop that extends into the Village of Wappingers Falls. There are two entrances to this park: one is within the Market Street Industrial Park (east entrance) and the west entrance is accessible through New Hamburg Park, Main Street, New Hamburg.

properties.site_name: Home of Franklin D. Roosevelt National Historic Site
properties.address: 4097 Albany Post Rd, Hyde Park, NY 12538

properties.site_description: Hudson Highlands State Park Preserve spans the Dutchess  Putnam County borders, from Peekskill to Beacon, and covers about 6000 acres. There is an extensive trail system, sweeping views and lots of activities such as boating, hiking, fishing and wildlife viewing.  Trail difficulty varies on the over 40 miles of trails in this and adjacent parks, and some areas can be a challenge, so it is important to have proper hiking shoes, water, and a trail map. Bannerman Island is part of the preserve, but you can only get there by water and it can only be seen by guided tours. Hunting is allowed but you must have a permit (only 200 are handed out during gun season).  Just to the south of the Dutchess County line in Cold Spring is Metro-North Railroads Breakneck Ridge stop right at the trail head on NYS Route 9D.
Created to ferry rail cars across the Hudson, this man-made peninsula now connects people to the river's power and majesty.

Montgomery Place, a 380-acre estate adjacent to the main Bard College campus and overlooking the Hudson River, is a designated National Historic Landmark set amid rolling lawns, woodlands, and gardens, against the spectacular backdrop of the Catskill Mountains.

properties.site_name: Pete and Toshi Seeger Riverfront Park
properties.site_description: A beautiful spot to sit and contemplate the majesty of the Hudson River, this park is named for Pete Seeger and his wife Toshi, lifelong Beacon residents.  Founder of Sloop Clearwater, Pete was an activist, influential folk musician, inductee in the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, and lover of the Hudson River.  This park, with its basketball courts, playground, and trails, is the northern terminus of a series of linked trails that extend all the way south to the tip of Dennings Point.

Poets Walk Park and the adjacent estate lands were protected by the Scenic Hudson Land Trust, and form a significant destination in the Hudson River Valley National Heritage Area.  Two miles of trails afford picturesque views of the landscape and the Hudson River.  This trail was originally envisioned by landscape architect Hans Jacob Ehlers, who was commissioned in 1849 by the Astor and Delano families to improve their grounds.  Ehlers designed Poets Walk as a shaded, streamside path in honor of Washington Irving and other literary figures who visited the estates. One is greeted by rolling meadows, woods, and rustic cedar pavilions, footbridges, and benches.  Dogs are welcomed (on leash at all times), as are hiking, cross country skiing, picnicking, and bird watching.
Reese Park is a 40 acre green space adjacent to the Wappinger Creek. The park has been preserved as an area to observe nature along scenic trails.

First an estate of the Livingston Family, the Barrytown Campus of the Unification Theological Seminary is situated on 250 acres on the shore of Tivoli South Bay.  It is here in 1868, at the original manor house, Massena, where the young Theodore Roosevelt first began his interest in nature and wildlife.  Now a Hudson River Greenway Trail, the  Father's Trail, starts at the main campus building and wends it way to the shore of Tivoli Bay, where one finds a contemplative overlook.  There are three interconnected trails on the property, two that can be accessed from River Road.  Hiking is allowed from dawn to dusk; campus buildings are not open to the public and there are no facilities.

Located along the Hudson River and next to the Walkway over the Hudson, this is a beautiful park for anyone looking for a relaxing place to enjoy a view. Although there is no playground, children can play at the Mid-Hudson Childrens Museum which is right next door. In addition, this park features the ground floor of the Walkway Over the Hudson Elevator, brick sidewalks, and several signs describing the industrial history of the Poughkeepsie waterfront. Trails connect it to Waryas and Kaal Rock Parks to the South, and the Walkway Over the Hudson above.

properties.address: 1 Vanderbilt Park Rd, Hyde Park, NY 12538
properties.site_description: Vanderbilt Mansion NHS, in terms of architecture, interiors, mechanical systems, road systems and landscape, is a remarkably complete example of a gilded-age country place, illustrating the political, economic, social, cultural, and demographic changes that occurred as America industrialized in the years after the Civil War.

properties.address: 39 N Mesier Av, Wappingers Falls, NY 12590
properties.site_description: Veterans Memorial Park is a spot of secluded wonder in the Village of Wappingers Falls.  With access from both Mesier Avenue and Spring Street, this park offers both beautiful views of, and access to Wappinger Lake for fishing and small boats.  In addition, there is an accessible playground, multi-sport fields, basketball, and both a pavilion and concession stand.

The Walkway Loop Trail unites a number of significant parks in both Dutchess and Ulster Counties:  The Walkway Over the Hudson, Mid Hudson Bridge, Franny Reese Park, and the historic neighborhoods of Poughkeepsie.  In total, the 3.6 mile long trail links recreational sites, restaurants, and shops, and is open year-round 7 a.m. till sunset (weather permitting).  This paved trail can be walked or biked, and dogs are permitted.

properties.site_name: Walkway Over the Hudson State Historic Park
properties.address: 1400 Walkway Over The Hudson, Poughkeepsie, NY 12601
properties.site_description: One of the busiest crossings of the Hudson River, the Poughkeepsie Railroad Bridge linked east and west on the Maybrook Line of the New Haven Railroad.  Built in 1889, it was an engineering marvel at 6,768 feet in length and 212 feet in height and was proposed as an Eighth Wonder of the World.  Now a very popular State Park, it offers stunning views of much of Ulster and Dutchess Counties, and the length of the Hudson River Valley.  Public bathrooms, vending machines, and concessions are available at either terminus to the west and east.

properties.photo_credits: Rendering of the future + POOL. Courtesy Friends of + POOL.
properties.use_limits: This facility is not currently open. Site development is in-progress.
properties.amenities_description: Full list of amenities to be updated in Spring 2023
properties.source: og source:  NA , edits from survey id:  c2136590-d59c-4e0e-80e7-774e0f1934d4
properties.program_description: Walking tours, river clean ups, exhibitions and other free community events take place on site as Friends of + POOL works to provide safe swimming access.

properties.site_description: Canale Playground is a small playground with a swing set and other climbing apparatus. It is located outside of the Village of Wappingers Falls Solar Field, at the terminus of the Wappinger Greenway Trail.

properties.address: RT-9D in C. Beacon, South on Hudson Ave, West on Dennings Ave
properties.site_description: Denning's Point State Park was once one of the largest brick manufactories in the world.  But before that, it was home to the eastern terminus of a Revolutionary War-period ferry to Newburgh.  This is also where researchers say Alexander Hamilton wrote the Federalist Papers in 1781.   1785 brought new ownership with the purchase by William Denning, of George Washingtons staff.  It was then in 1881 that Newburghs Homer Ramsdell took advantage of the clay deposits found on site to establish the brickyard that went on to produce 400,000 bricks per day!  After a number of subsequent industrial concerns, New York State bought the property in 1988 to establish Dennings Point State Park.  A flat 1.2-mile forest trail that loops around the perimeter of the peninsula, culminating with a great view of the Hudson River to the south. These trails join others that extend north into the City of Beacon, at the Metro-North Station.  The trails are closed seasonally during bald eagle nesting season; dogs must be on a leash at all times.

This park is named after the 2nd Earl of Limerick and the 5th Colonial Governor of New York, Thomas Dongan (1698). The park was dedicated to Dongan in 1930 by the then New York Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt for his many contributions which shaped New York early in its Colonial existence. It is a unique space because of its U-shaped design resulting from the Fallkill Creek running along the north side of the park. On site are shaded walking paths, playground equipment, a basketball court, and plenty of benches.

Doty Park is a small pocket park located at the end of a residential cul-de-sac adjacent to the Vanderbilt Mansion National Historic Site.  While it is small, there is a lot of shaded grassy areas, a playground, picnic table and benches. It is also adjacent to the Historic Stoutenberg Cemetery, the burial ground of the first Colonial settler to put roots in todays Town of Hyde Park.

Eastman Park was the Central Park of Poughkeepsie, having been developed along with the Eastman Terrace Housing by Harvey G. Eastman in 1865.  Along with a trail and playgrounds, the park includes Stitzel Field, the former home of the Poughkeepsie Chiefs professional baseball team, from 1947-1950.  This baseball field (and a couple of smaller practice fields) is still used by local leagues, and features bleachers and a field-side restaurant called Bennys 10th Inning, that serves hotdogs, seafood, and everything in between. A former YMCA, now abandoned, is at the northeast corner of the park.

James Temple was the Mayor of the Village of Wappinger Falls from 1947 to 1959.  Temple Memorial Park, named in his honor, includes a multi-sport field, playground, basketball court and ample parking.  In addition, this park is adjacent to the Wappinger Creek Greeenway Water Trail launch point, and just north of Reese Park in the Town of Wappinger.

Kaal Rock is a distinctive natural landmark on the shore of the Hudson River in the City of Poughkeepsie. The park surrounding it is the southern terminus of the Citys beautiful waterfront park complex (Waryas Park is just to the north).  With a playground, picnic tables and benches, and a section of the waterfront Greenway Trail, it is the perfect spot to socialize or have a picnic.  And, with its deep-water dock, one can see historic ships like the Sloop Clearwater or the recreation of Henryk Hudsons ship Halve Moon dock there during special events.
Lincoln Park is home to the Lincoln Park Soccer Club.  It is across the street from Eastman Park/Stitzel Field. This park contains one soccer field with portable bleachers, and a practice field.

Mesier Park and Homestead forms the public center of the Village of Wappingers Falls.  Originally a 750 acre farm property, it was established in 1741. Peter Mesier purchased it in 1776, and in 1891 his heirs sold the homestead and five acres to the Village of Wappingers Falls. Now a public park, the grounds host year-round community events.  The house is a museum open for guided tours.  Green spaces, along with shade trees, paved paths, a bandstand gazebo, and plenty of benches grace this significant property. The paths connect with adjacent sidewalks, and form a part of the Wappingers Creek Greenway Trail.  Dogs are welcome on a leash, and outdoor movies, a farm market, celebrations, community picnics, weddings, photo shoots and a holiday festival take place the year round.

properties.address: 75 Mills Mansion Dr, Hyde Park, NY 12580
properties.site_description: Margaret Lewis Norrie and Ogden & Ruth Livingston Mills State Parks are together called Mills-Norrie State Park. There is a lot to do here whether you are visiting for the day or camping out.  Dinsmore Golf Course, one of the oldest in the country, allows either 9 or 18-hole play; there is a pro shop and restaurant as well.  There are miles of trails for hiking, biking, cross-country skiing, snowshoeing or sledding. The park is great for picnicking and has as a full-service marina for boating and fishing access with slips for long-term rent. An outdoor riverfront pavilion is available for events.  The park is also the site of the Norrie Point Environmental Education Center (headquarters of the Hudson River National Estuarine Research Reserve), that offers school programs, workshops and professional training. And the crowning jewel of the park is the home of Ogden & Ruth Livingston Mills (Mills Mansion), open for tours and holiday events.
New Hamburg Park is in the hamlet of New Hamburg. This park contains tennis courts, a playground, a baseball field and part of the Wappinger Greenway Trail. It adjoins the Reese Audubon Sanctuary.

Pulaski is a large park that features many amenities including a well maintained pool, multi-use sport field, baseball field, a basketball court, tennis courts, all-abilities sidewalks, trails, and adequate parking. There are also several outdoor grills and picnic tables making this park great for families looking to spend the day outside.
In the Quiet Acres Park, there is a baseball field, playground, basketball court and pavilion. The back end of the park borders a section of the Wappinger Creek.
Riverview Park is in the hamlet of New Hamburg. It has a baseball field, basketball court and playground.

South Avenue Park is a neighborhood park offering a lot of amenities for all ages. There are basketball and tennis courts, lots of open green areas and updated playground equipment   summer camp and other community events are regularly held here, with sleigh riding when conditions permit.

Springside is the estate of Matthew Vassar, an English-born American who founded Vassar College in 1861. Despite many ideas to split up and sell off this property, Matthew Vassar decided to create an estate, designed by Andrew Jackson Downing, a founder of American Landscape Architecture. Although the property is much reduced in size today, Downings landscape still survives today.  Today the property is a National Historic Landmark, open to the public for its enjoyable walking trails, open spaces, and the restored Carpenter-Gothic gatehouse.

Tivoli Bay Multiple Use Area is an important upland habitat, estuarine reserve, and tidal coastal protected area, with an extensive trail network. This site, in the Town of Red Hook, links the Bard College Campus to the Village of Tivoli, on the shores of Tivoli Bay and the Hudson River. Consisting of two bays, South Bay and North Bay are separated by the Cruger Island Road (which is impassable, and submerged at most times).  Two Hudson River tributaries, Stony Creek and the Saw Kill, feed the Bays.  This is a globally rare wetland habitat (freshwater intertidal marsh and freshwater tidal swamp) that is open year-round for hunting, trapping, fishing, bird watching, hiking, mountain biking and canoeing (canoe launch).  An accessible canoe ramp (at the end of the Kidd Lane entrance) affords people of all abilities the opportunity to enjoy a paddle.  Four entry points with parking are available: Kidd Lane, NYS Route 9G, and Cruger Island Road and the Blythewood and Bay Roads.  There are no facilities at this park.

properties.address: 1 John M Flowers Cir, Poughkeepsie, NY 12601
properties.site_description: Waryas Park is the beautiful Front Yard of the City of Poughkeepsie.  Located at the west terminus of Main Street at John Flowers Circle, it is the definition of a leisurely pedestrian-friendly park setting, featuring several restaurants, playgrounds, and amenities such as a skateboard park, power boat ramp, kayak and canoe dock, benches, bleachers, picnic areas with grilles, and a pavilion for events, all of which overlook the Hudson River. Hudson River Greenway Trails connect Kaal Rock Park to the South with Upper Landing Park to the North.  Watch for the Hudson River Sloop Clearwater as it docks occasionally at the Kaal Rock mooring.

The Wilderstein Estate was the ancestral home of Daisy Suckley, a cousin and confidant of Franklin Roosevelt.  Originally part of the Rev. Freeborn Garretson Estate, this riverfront property was purchased by Thomas Suckley in 1852, and continuously occupied by the Suckleys until Daisys death in 1991.  Wilderstein (wild stone in German), was chosen to allude to a Native American petroglyph found nearby.  Over 40 acres in size, it includes the Mansion, now a museum.  Significantly, the restored grounds were designed by renowned landscape architect Calvert Vaux.  The three miles of trails he designed survive, and are available for walks today.  Highlighting nature, the trails afford views of the gardens and Hudson River. Check the Wilderstein website for hours and tour information.

properties.site_name: Hartshorne Woods Park, Black Fish Cove
properties.site_description: A hilly, forested 797-acre site overlooking the Navesink River, this park is among the highest elevations along the Atlantic Coast and features prominently in area history as a former coastal defense site. Known for its challenging trail system and scenic views, Hartshorne Woods is a popular park for area hikers, bicyclists and outdoor enthusiasts.
properties.use_limits: Hartshorne Woods Park has the most extensive and challenging series of trails (over 14 miles) in the Park System. Hardy hikers, bicyclists, and casual walkers can all find trails to their liking.
properties.accessibility_description: Cove is at end of a very steep paved park service Rd

properties.site_name: Hartshorne Woods Park, Clay Pit Creek
properties.site_description: Claypit Creek is one of the few areas in Hartshorne Woods with frontage on the water where the topography is conducive for visitor access (level, open etc.) A major reason for the acquisition was to provide waterfront access. Public improvements include enhanced access to the waterfront for fishing, crabbing, kayaking and general enjoyment as well as restrooms, expanded parking and accessible pathways that meet Americans with Disabilities Act standards.
properties.accessibility_description: Hard packed gravel and concrete walkways
properties.bike_path_accessible_description: Bike trails connect to other trails in Hartshorne

properties.site_description: Sandy beach, dog park, paved biking/walking trail, restrooms, picnic tables
properties.safety: poisen ivy around dunes
properties.use_limits: Short walk from parking to water's edge
properties.accessibility_description: Short walk from parking to water's edge
properties.bike_path_accessible_description: Paved bike path connecting Popamora point with Downtown Atlantic Highlands

properties.address: 261 W Front St, Red Bank, NJ 07701
RT-9A, West on Bleakley Ave, Right at fork to Joh n Walsh blvd, Follow signs for park

properties.site_description: Riverfront Park is located on the Hudson River, next to the Historic Hyde Park Train Station, there is much historic scenery to be appreciated.  In addition to the large greenspaces, there is a small playground with a mini rock wall, a large picnic pavilion and access to The Hyde Park Greenway Trail that runs through the park.  There is free public parking and maps can be found at the trailhead kiosk where you can walk to either the National Park service FDR Library and Museum to the South or to the Vanderbilt Historic Site to the North.

Riverfront Park is located at 11 River Road in the hamlet of New Hamburg. It is a great place to sit and relax and watch the Hudson River float by. The playground includes a swing set and train play set.
